key_title: Key to the species of Eragrostis

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the genera of Poaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Poaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1994). Poaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Plants glandular, the glands appearing as raised pits along leaf-sheaths and margins of blades and yellowish bands or patches closely below the nodes on the culms
Plants lacking raised pits along leaf-sheaths and margins of blades (but sometimes, in E. leptostachya, with yellowish glandular bands below nodes)
Spikelets 2–4 mm wide
Spikelets less than 2 mm wide
Lemmas leaden grey-green, 1–1.5 mm long, lateral veins very indistinct; anthers c. 1 mm long; panicle axis and branches devoid of glands
Lemmas green or often purplish, 1.5–2 mm long, lateral veins distinct; anthers c. 0.3 mm long; panicle axis and/or branches with glands (often sparse)
Not as above
Erect, wiry, tufted, mallee grass to 60 cm high, with rigid, narrowly inrolled leaf-blades; base of plant somewhat thickened or knotty, and woolly; spikelets laterally compressed
Spikelets terete or strongly biconvex, the two rows of florets overlapping at their bases, remaining so at maturity, not separated by a central groove; grasses predominantly of the mallee
Spikelets laterally compressed, the two rows of florets often separated by a central groove or channel, becoming loose at maturity

Spikelets sessile or subsessile (pedicels, except those of terminal spikelets, less than 0.5 mm long), commonly clustered and curved to one side, green and/or pinkish; glumes and lemmas persistent; lemma with prominently thickened nerves, the lateral one midway between midrib and margin; culms often procumbent or only weakly ascending

Spikelets distinctly pedicellate, not or barely curved, usually dark purple at least initially; glumes and lemmas soon deciduous; lemma nerves not prominently thickened and the lateral nerves nearer to margin than midrib
Spikelets shining; lemmas acute to obtuse, the lowest lemma of spikelet to 1.4 mm long; anthers minute, almost circular, to 0.2 mm long
Spikelets dull; lemmas very broadly obtuse, truncate or broadly emarginate, the lowest lemma of spikelet 1.5 mm long or more; anthers c. linear, 0.4 mm long or more
Largest spikelets clearly more than 2 mm long and 1 mm wide
Spikelets to 2 mm long and 1 mm wide; panicle delicate, rather narrow but with spreading capillary branches
Lateral nerves on lemma conspicuous, ridged, approaching or reaching the margin
Lateral nerves indistinct, not or barely forming a ridge and usually not reaching beyond halfway to the margin
Pedicels without a yellow band below spikelet
Pedicels each with a yellowish band shortly below spikelet
Perennials; glumes persisting until all or most of the firm lemmas have fallen
Weedy annual; glumes falling before the membranous lemmas
Anthers 3; grain 0.7–0.8 mm long; inflorescence with branches finally spreading, the spikelets spaced along the branches
Anthers 2; grain 0.5 mm long; inflorescence remaining narrow and spike-like (but usually interrupted), the spikelets produced in close clusters
Rhizomatous and/or stoloniferous perennials, leaves mostly cauline; culms usually branched, wiry or cane-like; grasses of shallow lakes and overflows in the west and north of the State
Tufted annuals or perennials, leafy at base; culms rarely branched below inflorescence

Culms cane-like, to 5 mm diam., much-branched, but not producing stolons, usually prominently waxy at least along younger parts; lemma thinly membranous and obtuse or erose at apex; rare grass of far north-west

Culms wiry, to c. 3 mm diam., generally not much-branched, occasionally producing aerial stolons, not waxy; lemma membranous, more or less acute and entire at apex; occasional grass of heavy clay soils
Grain neither deep red nor ornamented; spikelets usually with more than 5 florets
Grain deep red, ornamented by a raised, honeycomb-pattern; spikelets rarely with more than 5 florets
Lemmas finely scabrous between dorsal and lateral nerve as well as the nerves themselves; grain slender, c. 1 mm long; annual; dubiously Victorian, known from a single 1898 Grampians specimen
Lemmas smooth, or scaberulous along dorsal nerve only; if grain ever slender and 1 mm long, then plants perennial
Neither basal sheaths hairy nor leaf tips very fine and curled; grain c. 0.5–0.7 mm long; annuals or perennials
Sheaths of lower leaves hairy at base; leaf tips usually very fine and curly; grain c. 1 mm long; perennials
Pedicels without a yellow band below spikelet
Pedicels each with a yellow band shortly below spikelet

Lowest panicle branches glabrous in axils or if with a few hairs, these much less than 4 mm long; lower glume more than 0.7 mm long; grain concave dorsally; plants annual or perennial, usually more than 50 cm high

Lowest branch(es) of panicle with a sparse tuft of fine hairs c. 4 mm long in axil (rarely the axils glabrous); lower glume less than 0.7 mm long; grain convex dorsally; plants annual, usually less than 50 cm high
